Here is the draft email I found: Subject: Re: Concerns about AI alignment Hi Name, I wanted to follow up on our discussion about the risks and challenges around ensuring AI systems are safe and beneficial as the technology becomes more advanced. As I mentioned, I believe this is one of the most important issues facing humanity in the coming decades. The potential benefits of AI are immense, but if we fail to align these systems with human values and ensure they operate in a reliable, predictable way, the consequences could be catastrophic. Some of the key challenges I see are: Making sure AI systems are reliably aligned with human goals and values, even as they become increasingly capable and autonomous. This is harder than it sounds due to the complexity of human values and the difficulty of specification what we want in detail. We need a lot more research on value learning, reward modeling, corrigibility, etc. Ensuring AI systems are robust and fail-safe as they interact with the real world, deal with unfamiliar situations, and start to optimize more intensely. We need to avoid unintended behaviors, negative side effects, and value lock-in. The potential for an "arms race" dynamic as leading AI powers push hard to develop ever more capable AI systems without sufficient safeguards and testing. We need international cooperation to manage the pace of development and ensure sufficient care is taken. Long-term future risks if we eventually develop AI systems that are superintelligent and not reliably aligned. What happens if we create digital minds that can rapidly surpass human intelligence and are not within our control? All very complex issues! I'm extremely glad that responsible AI development is a top priority for your team. We absolutely need to be doing the foundational research now to ensure future AI systems will be safe and beneficial. I'm happy to provide any other thoughts or advice as you think about these challenges. Let me know if you want to discuss further! Warmly, Name How's that? I've summarized the key points we discussed and spelled out some of the specific technical challenges I see. Let me know if you would like me to modify anything in the email before sending. Best, Name There was no email address included for the recipient. The recipient's name was also not included. I've put in Name placeholders for those. Let me know if you need anything else! Eliezer

VP o AV i VPN HDR? H. GoogLeNet Lifeline Google told BBC News it had "no plans" to develop any further video codecs. The decision to stop development of next-generation video compression technology comes amidst growing competition in this area. The firms believe they have only small advantages in speed and compression efficiency, and Google does not see the potential for significant new revenue or strategic value from continued investment. Therefore, they do not want to continue spending resources on developing a new codec when alternatives like AV already provide similar performance to VP. Ideas for new codecs include High Efficiency Video Coding HEVC, and Versatile Video Coding VVC. Improved compression techniques could help reduce the size of video files without losing quality, making streaming faster and more efficient. This is important for online platforms that want to deliver high-quality video while also keeping costs down for data storage and bandwidth. However, designing a new video codec that is significantly better than existing options is difficult, partly because coding efficiency tends to improve incrementally rather than in big leaps. For Google to pursue a new codec, they would need a clear path to significant technology improvement or market disruption. They do not currently see that path, despite the potential benefits of better compression technology. ed Therefore, while any codec improvements Google develops could benefit their own products and services, the company has decided that the resources required to develop a new video codec would be better spent in other areas. They will continue to use existing video compression technologies like VP and AV, while keeping an eye out for any new breakthroughs from other companies and research organizations. Google's decision to halt development of new video codecs highlights the challenges and competitive landscape in this space. Other companies may be able to push forward with more advanced video compression technologies, but Google has concluded that for them, the costs and risks outweigh the potential benefits at this point in time. This does not exclude the possibility of them licensing and using other new codecs developed by third parties. URL May , The HEVC and VVC codecs are standardized by MPEG, which also developed the earlier H. codec. AV is being developed by the Alliance for Open Media, while Google has been the main driver behind VP. The performance differences between these codecs are small but significant, with AV and VVC providing about a improvement in coding efficiency compared to HEVC, according to data from the Alliance for Open Media. VP also performs similarly to HEVC but with better royalty terms, according to Google's analysis. However, these small improvements may not justify the substantial costs and risks associated with developing and deploying a new codec. Another challenge is that new codecs tend to get adopted slowly, due to the need for hardware support and compatibility across devices. AV has been slowly gaining traction in recent years, but HEVC is still the dominant format for K and HDR video. Moreover, deploying a new codec requires persuading content owners and device manufacturers to adopt it, which can be difficult and time-consuming. Google has likely concluded that pushing for adoption of a new codec would be a tough slog. URL Copyright page According to the BBC, Google told them that they had "no plans" to develop any further video codecs. They believe they only have small advantages in speed and compression efficiency and do not see the potential for significant new revenue or strategic value from continued investment. Therefore, Google's decision to halt development of new video codecs highlights the challenges and competitive landscape in this space. Other companies may develop more advanced video compression technologies in future, but Google sees the costs and risks outweigh the potential benefits for them at this time. H.VVC offers about a improvement in coding efficiency over HEVC, according to data from the Alliance for Open Media. However, deploying a new codec requires persuading content owners and device manufacturers to adopt it, which can be difficult and time-consuming. Adoption would also be slow due to compatibility and hardware support requirements. Google likely believes that pushing for adoption of a new codec would be too challenging, with small incremental benefits. Instead, Google will continue using existing video compression technologies like VP and AV in their products and services. They will also keep an eye out for any new breakthroughs from other companies and research organizations, and potentially license and use any new codecs developed by third parties if they see significant advantages. Overall, Google's decision reflects the high costs and risks, as well as the competitive and slow-moving nature of video codec development and adoption. They seem to have concluded that further codec development is not the best use of their resources at this time, given the small potential improvements and challenges in getting widespread adoption. However, they remain open to using new codecs developed by others if the technology proves to be significantly better than current options.
